2925 LDEQ Facility Identification

The City of Alexandria Wastewater Department Chlorination System is located at 1212 Hudson Blvd., Alexandria, LA.   Chlorine for the chlorination of the City's wastewater effluent is stored at this location.  On average, 20,000 pounds of chlorine are stored in one ton cylinders.  In case of a chlorine leak, the City of Alexandria has an emergency response policy which requires City personnel to notify LA State Police Hazmat by calling the 911 center.  Local fire and police departments are notified.  These emergency personnel are used to assist in evaluating citizens in the affected area.  

The worst case incident used EPA's RMP Comp(TM) model which projected the release of 2000 pounds of chlorine in ten minutes.  The affected area, 1.3 miles, included approximately 9188 citizens. Public facilities such as hospital, prison, and major commerical areas are located in the potential affected area.  The alternative release model used EMP's RMP Guidance for WasteWater Treatment Plants Reference Tables or Equation.  The model was based on 99 pounds/minute release affecting an area, 0.2 miles, withapproximately 40 citizens potentially affected.   Currently, the City uses daily inspections and a comprehensive preventative maintenance program to ensure the system is operating properly.  There are  active, emergency shutdown systems, and passive mitigation, enclosures,  being used at the facility at the present time.

Plant personnel have been properly trained to handle chlorine stored in one ton cylinders.  Formal and on-the-job training ensures plant personnel have the necessary knowledge and skill to properly maintain the chlorination system.

The City of Alexandria has no history of reportable release for chlorine at this site.  There has been no injury or property loss associated with this chemical. 

The City of Alexandria Wastewater Treatment Plant Chlorination System at Hudson Blvd. is included in witten community emergency response p

lan.  The facility does not have its own written emergency response plan.  The facility notifies the 911 Center which contacts the State Police HazMat, local fire and police departments for assistance.  

The City of Alexandria is reviewing possible active and passive mitigation in order to improve safety at the facility.  On-going operator training and preventative maintenance continue to be key tools to ensure the safety of the public.
